answer_found_by_llm: There is a clear indication of port scanning. One internal host (IP 10.251.96.4) exhibits behavior typical of a port scan by sending SYN packets across a wide range of destination ports on the target (IP 10.251.96.5), which is a hallmark of scanning activity.
The port scanning activity is being carried out by the IP address 10.251.96.4.
The suspicious host scanned ports 1 to 1024 and additionally port 48994.
The suspicious host conducted a TCP SYN (half-open) port scan.
No additional reconnaissance tools were detected; the capture only indicates the use of a TCP SYN scan.
There is an indication of a web shell upload. The traffic contains an HTTP GET request for “/shell”, indicating that the uploaded web shell is named “shell”.
There is an indication of a file upload. The capture shows evidence of file-upload HTTP headers, and the file "dbfunctions.php" is used as the upload endpoint.
The captured traffic shows that the attacker executed commands through the web shell by passing commands via the "cmd" parameter.
Yes, a reverse shell connection was established. The attacker used a Python-based reverse shell to gain remote access.
The reverse shell connection was established on port 4422.
